titleStmt.title: Coping through Precise Labeling of Emotions: A Deep Learning Approach to Studying Emotional Granularity in Consumer Reviews

affiliation.orgName: Atefeh Jebeli is a PhD student in Information Systems

analytic.title: Coping through Precise Labeling of Emotions: A Deep Learning Approach to Studying Emotional Granularity in Consumer Reviews

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: When describing their emotions, people may demonstrate emotional expertise by differentiating between emotions when using emotional labels, or use emotion labels interchangeably to indicate a general valence. The authors develop a novel deep-learning-based method to measure the granularity with which people describe their emotions via language. They examine the role of emotional granularity in consumer decision-making, particularly in how consumers rate unpleasant service experiences (e.g., service failures) in online reviews. Consistent with the notion that granularity in describing negative emotions is associated with more successful self-regulation of negative emotions, consumers who express their negative emotions more granularly in review texts tend to rate businesses less negatively following service failures. Furthermore, a greater temporal distance between an experience and describing it leads to greater granularity in describing negative emotions. Consequently, a greater temporal distance between the service experience and writing the review predicts more positive ratings following service failures. The results have implications for a) understanding the role of emotional granularity in consumer decision making; b) understanding the predictors of online review ratings, as an important category of consumer decisions; and c) profiling consumers based on emotion regulation abilities inferred from the online content they generate.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Consumers often use a variety of emotion labels (e.g., angry, frustrated, stressed, etc.) to describe how they feel as a result of consumption experiences. Research in psychology over the past three decades has shown that people differ in the degree of granularity with which they describe their emotions (e.g., Barrett et al. 2001;Barrett 2004;Erbas et al. 2018;Kashdan, Barrett, and McKnight 2015). Often viewed as an indicator of "expertise in emotion" , emotional granularity describes individuals' ability or skill to represent their emotional experience in a nuanced and specific manner, often marked through language (Lee, Lindquist, and Nam 2017). A substantial stream of empirical research shows that granularity in negative emotions predicts more successful coping strategies and improves self-regulation to minimize the unwanted impact of negative emotions on behaviors such as binge drinking and aggression (Kashdan et al. 2010;Kashdan et al. 2015;Starr et al. 2020;Tomko et al. 2015).
Despite the documented significance of emotional granularity in predicting people's behaviors, its role in consumer decision making has not been investigated.

In this research, we investigate the role of granularity in negative emotions in consumer decision making, following unpleasant service experiences (e.g., service failures), in the context of online reviews. As an empirical setting, online reviews include an overall rating, which is a holistic judgment about the business, as well as textual descriptions of the consumer experience.

These textual descriptions provide valuable insights into the psychological processes that led to the holistic judgement (i.e., the rating). Furthermore, a consumer's decision about the rating to assign to a business after a (failed) service experience is extremely important to the business' success (Chevalier and Mayzlin 2006;Floyd et al. 2014;Proserpio and Zervas 2017;Vana and Lambrecht 2021;Varga and Albuquerque 2023;Wu et al. 2015). Thus, we seek to provide more insight on what shapes this managerially important type of consumer decision.

Methods developed to measure emotional granularity in extant research primarily measure the construct at the trait level (i.e., individual differences in ability) . However, the construct may also be conceptualized at the situation-level (Barrett and Gross 2001), which is more relevant for studying it in the context of consumer experience. We utilize the BERT Large Language Model (Devlin et al. 2018) to develop a novel deep-learning-based method that enables us to measure the granularity with which consumers describe their emotions in online reviews. We then investigate how the granularity in negative emotions expressed in the online review text impacts consumers' rating of businesses following service failures. Furthermore, we investigate how the temporal distance between the consumption experience and the writing of the review, as a situational factor, predicts reviewers' granularity when describing their negative emotions, and ultimately impacts the rating assigned to the business.

We present novel propositions by building on previous research which shows an association between granularity in negative emotions and successful emotional self-regulation (e.g., Barrett et al. 2001). First, we propose that, particularly when the overall service experience is negative, greater granularity in describing negative emotions is associated with more positive ratings of the business. This proposition stems from the fact that describing negative emotions more granularly may be associated with better self-regulation to minimize the unwanted impact of negative emotions on one's rating decision (i.e., lower likelihood of 'penalizing' the business) after a negative consumption experience. Second, we propose that a greater temporal distance between a negative consumption experience and the writing of a review increases reviewers' granularity in describing the negative emotions, which then contributes to more positive ratings of negative service experiences.

Our research primarily contributes to the stream of research on the role of context specificity of emotions in consumer decision making (e.g., Cavanaugh, Bettman, Luce 2015; Allard and White 2015; Raghunathan and Pham 1999), the factors that influence consumer review ratings (Aerts, Smits, and Verlegh 2017;Huang et al. 2016;Schoenmueller, Netzer, and Stahl 2020), and the psychology of consumer language (e.g., Berger et al. 2019;Boghrati and Berger 2023;Packard and Berger 2023).
In the following, we present the theoretical background of our research, followed by an explanation of the method we have developed to measure emotional granularity in language use.

We then present our empirical work which includes seven (presented as five main and two auxiliary) controlled studies, in addition to two field studies analyzing about 13 million reviews from Yelp and Tripadvisor. Finally, we discuss the contributions and implications of our research.

div.head: Emotional Granularity
div.p: A large body of research in psychology over the past three decades has shown that while some people are skilled at using differentiated and discrete emotion categories (e.g., agitated, angry, sad) to describe their emotions, others are not so skilled. This latter group instead communicates the general valence of how they feel by interchangeably using similarly valenced emotion labels (e.g., Barrett et al. 2001;Barrett 2004;Erbas et al. 2018;Kashdan et al. 2015).

Psychological interest in emotional granularity stems largely from a broader interest in understanding people's competencies in recognizing and using their emotions (e.g., Barrett 2004;Quoidbach et al. 2014). Valence and arousal provide a foundational framework for understanding core affect, which represents the fundamental physiological responses associated with an emotional experience (Russell and Barrett 1999). However, emotions are not merely physiological responses-they are actively constructed through a complex interplay of contextual factors, cognitive processes, and social interpretations that give them meaning and specificity (Barrett 2006). Individuals draw on this rich repository of contextual knowledge, beyond core affect, to categorize an experience into an emotion (Barrett 2006). This contextual knowledge includes the causes of the event (e.g., "angry with someone," "sad about something"; Barrett 2001) and its cultural meaning (Mesquita and Frijda 1992). It also includes individuals' cognitive (re)appraisals of the event (Lazarus 1991). For example, whether one (re)frames a disappointing outcome as an unavoidable difficulty or a personal failure, impacts whether they categorize their emotion as frustration or sadness. These (re)appraisals are influenced not only by the relevance and alignment of the event's outcome with one's various goals, but also by attributions of responsibility, which is itself influenced by the extent to which one adopts the perspective of other parties involved (Lazarus 1991).

While the theory of emotional granularity does not primarily concern which specific labels people assign to different emotions (e.g., whether they call a feeling "sadness" or "frustration") 1 , it argues for variances in people's ability to take into account contextual 1 The theory of emotional granularity is built upon the Theory of Constructed Emotion (Barrett 2017), which argues that emotions are not innate, fixed responses but are instead, dynamically constructed by the brain through core affect (valence and arousal) combined with conceptual knowledge. In this view, what one person calls "sadness" may be a very different emotional experience from what another person calls "sadness." This contrasts with Functional Views of emotion, which propose that core emotions have distinct neural and physiological signatures. While a lively scientific debate between constructionist and functionalist perspectives of emotion continues, this debate is less central to our research, as our predictions hold regardless of one's stance on the issue.

information when experiencing and articulating emotions. Accordingly, those with high emotional granularity have developed a more diverse set of mental representations associated with different emotional experiences and thus categorize similarly valenced emotional experiences into a broader set of categories using different emotion labels (Barrett 2006). Barrett's (2006) example of two participants responding to the events of September 11, 2001, helps illustrate emotional granularity and differentiate it from other constructs. Participant A said, "My first reaction was terrible sadness ... But the second reaction was that of anger, because you can't do anything with the sadness." In contrast, Participant B said, "I felt a bunch of things I couldn't put my finger on. Maybe anger, confusion, fear. I just felt bad on September 11 th . Really bad." Participant A clearly differentiated between sadness and anger by associating distinct contextual cues with them (e.g., anger's action-oriented nature compared to sadness).

Participant B, however, used multiple emotion labels (sadness, confusion, fear) interchangeably to describe a generalized unpleasant state. Despite using fewer labels, Participant A demonstrates higher emotional granularity by precisely distinguishing between emotions.

This example highlights several aspects of emotional granularity. First, emotional granularity reflects having differentiated cognitive structures for various emotions, rather than simply reflecting the number or variety of emotion labels used. Just like a researcher with expertise in consumer experience uses terms like 'satisfaction,' 'loyalty,' or 'repeat purchase' with precision-applying each term only when it aligns with the research focus or distinguishing between them when they all apply-an individual with high emotional granularity is similarly selective in their use of emotion labels, employing them only when they precisely capture the nuanced emotions they are experiencing. As such, emotional granularity emphasizes the ability to precisely identify and label emotions. It does not make assumptions about people's abilities or propensity to experience different emotions. Thus, emotional granularity differs from the complexity or variety of negative emotions experienced; or emotional ambivalence (i.e., whether people have experienced negative and positive emotions together) .

Second, emotional granularity is distinct from the intensity of the felt emotions (Rocklage et al. 2018) or one's certainty in their emotional reaction (Rocklage et al. 2023). In this example, both participants were similarly unsettled and certain that their reaction was negative. However, the less granular Participant B uses negative emotion labels interchangeably because they do not have differentiated cognitive structures for these similarly valenced emotions. The seemingly uncertain language used by Participant B-i.e., "I felt a bunch of things I couldn't put my finger on"-does not reflect uncertainty about the negativity of the experience but rather uncertainty about which specific label to use, stemming from a lack of differentiated cognitive structures.

Third, emotional granularity reflects one's "expertise" in their emotions specifically , and not in their consumption-domain expertise (e.g., photography, coffee, etc.). While both these forms of expertise involve having differentiated cognitive structures, emotional granularity involves cognitive structures for emotions (e.g., "sadness" is different from "frustration") whereas domain expertise involves cognitive structures for domain knowledge (e.g., "cold brew" is different from "espresso"). Finally, emotional granularity is not necessarily linked to lower emotional focus (lower "emotionality"; . People with high granularity may still experience emotions with engagement. Rather than dampening emotional engagement ("emotional numbness"), emotional granularity allows for a more nuanced understanding and expression of emotions. The third and final distinction clarify how our work differs from prior research concerning the effect of consumption-domain expertise on reducing the "emotionality" of individuals' emotional descriptions , as both the key predictor and outcome variables in our work differ from the earlier work.

Emotional Granularity and Improved Self-Regulation in the Face of Negative Emotions Prior research has primarily used experience sampling methods to examine the associated outcomes of emotional granularity at the trait level. Experience sampling involves prompting participants to rate the intensity of a set of predetermined emotions across various emotionevoking situations. The underlying assumption in experiment sampling is that different life situations are unlikely to elicit the same set of similarly valenced emotions. Hence, a person whose ratings consistently correlate across different situations is considered to have low emotional granularity because this correlation reflects an inability to distinguish between emotions of the same valence.

Importantly, given the qualitative difference between positive and negative emotions, researchers have usually investigated the effects of granularity in negative and positive emotions separately (e.g., Barrett et al. 2001). Much of this research has focused on negative emotions, consistently demonstrating that greater granularity in negative emotions is associated with improved emotional self-regulation, more effective coping strategies, and, consequently, enhanced psychological health and well-being (e.g., Kashdan et al. 2015).

Granularity in negative emotions is associated with having a broader set of mental representations for negative emotions, which also includes a broader set of coping and selfregulation strategies that can be tapped into when needed (Barrett and Gross 2001). Furthermore, because individuals with higher negative emotional granularity identify and consider the context in which they had a negative experience, they exert better self-regulation to minimize the unwanted impact of these emotions on behaviors. For example, Tomko et al. (2015) found that higher granularity in negative emotions predicts lower impulsivity among individuals with borderline personality disorder even after accounting for the overall levels of negative affect.
Similarly, Kashdan et al. (2010) found that, even at similar levels of intense negative emotions, individuals with high negative emotional granularity are less likely to engage in alcohol abuse.

Furthermore, individuals with high emotional granularity are less likely to allow external manipulations of incidental negative emotions to influence their moral judgments (Cameron, Payne, and Doris 2013). This body of evidence suggests that although coping in the context of emotional granularity may sometimes involve reducing the intensity of negative emotions, it also involves a greater ability to manage and minimize the unwanted influence of negative emotions on one's decisions and behavior through better self-regulation. In our research we focus on the effect of this second form of coping, and use the term "coping success" consistent with this latter effect: success in reducing the unwanted impact of negative emotions on one's decisions.

While extant research has primarily investigated the association between negative granularity and coping success at the trait level, one can also conceptualize the construct at the situation level. Previous conceptualizations of the construct account for situation-level variance in emotional granularity: even when emotional granularity is considered as an individual-level skill, one can agree that individuals' ability and/or motivation to use this skill varies from one situation to another. Thus, situation-level variances in experiencing and/or recalling one's emotions granularly have been previously theorized (Barrett and Gross 2001). However, there is no prior empirical evidence showing that an individual would more successfully cope with a specific negative experience if they used negative emotion labels more granularly to describe this experience (i.e., situation-level analysis). Thus, our research is the first to test the association between granularity in negative emotions and coping success at the situation level through language use, and to study the implications of this association in terms of how consumers rate businesses on online review platforms following service failures.

We note that while most existing research on emotional granularity has focused on granularity in negative emotions, a smaller body of trait-level evidence suggests that granularity in positive emotions is associated with improved health and well-being outcomes as well (see Tan, Wachsmuth, and Tugade 2022 for a review). This line of research argues that positive emotional granularity enables individuals to 'broaden and build' their mental resources, equipping them to better navigate negative emotions (Fredrickson 2001). In our research, for two reasons, we will focus our theoretical discussions and predictions on negative emotional granularity. First, given the trait-level nature of findings in prior research, it is possible that the previously observed effects of positive emotional granularity are partially driven by correlations between negative and positive granularity, as individuals who are more granular in their negative emotions are also likely to be granular in their positive emotions (the "broaden-and-build" argument itself implies an effect of positive granularity through negative granularity). Second, our focus in this paper is on individuals' situation-level descriptions of their emotions following negative service experiences (e.g., service failures). Considering the motivational differences between negative and positive emotions, and the greater relevance of negative emotions in the service-failure context, we find a focus on negative emotional granularity more appropriate for the scope of our research. That said, we will include exploratory analyses of the effects of granularity in positive emotions in our empirical investigations, where applicable.

div.head: Granularity in Negative Emotions, Emotional Self-Regulation, and Online Review Ratings
div.p: The rating (usually on a 5-star scale) that a consumer posts on review platforms indicates a decision that they make about the business after a consumption experience (Sridhar and Srinivasan 2012). This decision is subject to various psychological processes and is not merely an objective score of the negativity or positivity of the experiences. Consistently, previous research has shown that beyond the quality of the experience itself, processes related to social influence and conformity (Goes, Lin, and Au Yeung 2014;Moe and Trusov 2011;Sridhar and Srinivasan 2012), psychological distance (Huang et al. 2016), the design of the review platform (Aerts et al. 2017), and reviewer status (Zhang, Wei, and Zeng 2020) influence customer ratings.

While the role of coping and emotional self-regulation in consumer decision making has been explored extensively (e.g., Duhachek 2005;Duhachek and Kelting 2009;Faraji-Rad and Lee 2022;St. James, Handelman, and Taylor 2011;Raghunathan et al. 2006;Raghunathan and Pham 1999;), to the best of our knowledge, previous research has not examined how these processes affect consumers' online review ratings. However, it is reasonable to expect that consumers' ability to regulate the impact of their negative emotions on their behavior would affect how they rate businesses following service failures. Specifically, consumers are often aware of the potentially detrimental effects that extremely low ratings can have on a business' success. As a result, they may be motivated to control their negative emotional response, and hesitate to give excessively negative ratings, even when faced with dissatisfaction. Still, not providing an extremely low rating despite a low-quality service experience-i.e., not punishing the business despite service failure-requires some level of emotional self-regulation to minimize and control the unwanted impact of the unpleasant emotions on the rating decision. We argue that granularity in describing one's negative emotions will be associated with better selfregulation of the impact of the negative emotions on the rating decision; and thus, granularity in describing negative emotions in the online review text will be associated with a more positive rating of the business. Furthermore, the self-regulation of negative emotions is most applicable in situations where service quality has been particularly low (e.g., service failures) and the overall experience has been negative. While one may have minor quibbles about positive experiences (e.g., "this was the best hotel I've been to, but the price of drinks was shocking"), such instances are less likely to require emotional regulation. Consistent with this argument, previous research has demonstrated that the effects of emotional granularity are stronger when individuals' overall experience is more negative (e.g., Kashdan et al. 2010). Thus, we expect the effect of negative emotional granularity on ratings to be especially strong when the overall experience has been negative.

While the primary focus of our research is to investigate how situation-level negative granularity impacts rating decisions, it is also worth considering whether marketers can leverage reviewers' negative granularity on review platforms as a psychological targeting or profiling tool (Matz and Netzer 2017;. Specifically, marketers might infer individuals' traitlevel negative granularity from their earlier reviews to predict their future ratings. Such an approach could be valuable for practitioners, as it suggests that marketers might selectively solicit new reviews (e.g., through email campaigns) from reviewers who exhibit higher negative granularity in their past online reviews. In line with our situation-level proposition, we propose that reviewers who, on average, demonstrate higher historical negative granularity in their previous reviews will provide more positive ratings for service failures.

div.head: Temporal Distance and Emotional Granularity
div.p: A last question to consider is how the passage of time between an experience and describing one's emotions from it influences the granularity with which individuals describe their negative emotions. While one might argue that the passage of time could contribute to forgetting and reduce the consideration of contextual cues in descriptions, prior research suggests otherwise. Specifically, individuals' memories for emotion-laden events tend to be particularly robust and more enduring than their memories for objective details (e.g., Rocklage and Luttrell 2021;Kensinger 2009). Thus, even as some specific details of the service experience may fade over time, the emotional essence and its related context are likely to persist.

Instead, with the passage of time, individuals are more likely to engage in cognitive reappraisal, a process that involves reinterpreting the emotional experience (Lazarus 1991). As emotional reactions to events become less visceral over time (Chang and Pham 2013;Ekman and Davidson 1994), these reappraisals allow individuals to better process and contextualize their negative emotions, potentially leading to more granular descriptions of negative emotions. Therefore, we propose that greater temporal distance between the time of receiving a service and the time of reviewing the business (hereafter, "temporal distance") will be positively associated with granularity in describing negative emotions in the review text. Consequently, this increased granularity should contribute to more successful self-regulation of negative emotions for service failures. Thus, we propose that a greater temporal distance will be associated with a more positive rating of the business following service failures.

We should note that the effect of temporal distance on review rating has been investigated in previous research. Specifically, Huang et al. (2016) has shown that greater psychological distance, including temporal distance between the experience and the review, increases the positivity of ratings. Our research adds to the findings by Huang et al. (2016) by recognizing the mediating role of emotional granularity in this effect, and introducing the overall service experience moderator: we propose that the effect of temporal distance is particularly strong when the overall service experience is negative and thus, self-regulation of emotions is relevant.

div.head: MEASURING EMOTIONAL GRANULARITY THROUGH TEXTUAL DATA
div.p: As explained, experience sampling, which for the past three decades has been the main method used to measure emotional granularity (e.g., Larsen and Cutler 1996), produces a traitlevel assessment of individuals' emotional granularity, which is not ideal for addressing situation-level research questions. The method also requires a high degree of participant involvement, which is problematic in the applied field of marketing because it reduces the actionability of the construct in practice. Finally, to avoid participant fatigue, only a finite set of emotion labels can be used in experience sampling, which limits the range of emotions that can be captured using this method. Given the limitations of experience sampling, there have been calls in psychological research to develop methods that directly infer individuals' emotional granularity from their language (Kashdan et al. 2015). Furthermore, in the marketing domain, there has been an increasing interest in relying on the richness of the unstructured data to study consumer behavior (Berger et al. 2019;Packard and Berger 2023).

We propose that, given the close relationship between emotional granularity and language, an individual's level of emotional granularity in a given text can be assessed by examining whether they use different emotion labels in distinct meaning contexts. The theory of emotional granularity suggests that individuals with higher granularity possess more differentiated cognitive structures for different emotions, making them less likely to use multiple emotion labels to describe the same feeling. Experience sampling methods have been applied consistently with this theory: assuming that different life situations do not elicit the exact same set of emotions, researchers ask participants to rate their experience of a predetermined set of emotions across various situations. An individual who reports their emotions in a highly correlated manner across different situations is considered less granular, as this pattern suggests difficulty in distinguishing between the different emotions evoked by distinct life experiences.

However, in a situation-level analysis, we lack access to the person's emotional experiences across multiple situations. Therefore, to evaluate granularity within a single situation, we can invert the logic of the experience sampling method and ask: if an individual uses multiple emotion labels in their description of the situation, do they apply these labels to convey different contextual meanings (e.g., describe different aspects of the experience)? Using different emotion labels to describe the same situational context implies less precision in distinguishing between different emotional states/labels and hence lower granularity.

To elaborate further with the example of participants from Barrett (2006) discussed earlier, the more granular Participant A, has used "sadness" and "anger" in more distinct manner in their description, whereas the less granular Participant B has used these labels less distinctly.
Swapping "sadness" and "anger" in Participant A's description would significantly alter its meaning, whereas making the same switch in Participant B's description would have a less pronounced effect.

Thus, to measure the emotional granularity expressed in a text, a researcher must first identify the emotion labels used in the text, code how each label is applied based on dimensions that capture its distinctiveness in context, and finally use these dimensions to assess how differently the emotion labels have been used from one another.

Identifying emotion labels. The first step in our method involves distinguishing words that describe an emotion (e.g., "sad," "apprehensive," "hesitant") from words that do not. Two relevant glossaries for this purpose are the dictionaries from the Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count (LIWC) software (Pennebaker et al. 2001;Tausczik and Pennebaker 2010) and the Evaluative Lexicon (Rocklage, Rucker, and Nordgren 2018). LIWC includes a dictionary of words with positive and negative associations, which also includes non-emotion labels. The Evaluative Lexicon provides a dictionary of evaluative adjectives such as "wonderful" and "fantastic," which may not include a full set of emotion labels. We instructed a language expert (with a PhD in linguistics) to produce a comprehensive set of positive and negative emotion labels by a) considering all terms in these dictionaries; b) excluding any terms that would not be considered as emotion labels (e.g., "rapist," "protest"); c) referring to the English dictionary to include any additional emotion labels; d) coding whether each label in the final list of labels describe positive or a negative emotion. This exercise resulted in a glossary of 1,379 negative and 887 positive emotion labels which we use to classify each word in a given text (e.g., a review) into one of three categories: (1) non-emotional (no match in the glossary), (2) negative (matches a negative emotion label), or (3) positive (matches a positive label). We match words by considering their stems. Given the qualitative differences between negative and positive emotions, we compute granularity separately for each category when applicable.

BERT Embeddings as Context Encodings. The second step is to code how each label is applied in the text, based on dimensions that capture its contextual distinctiveness. Core to this step is the use of the Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) encoder (Devlin et al. 2018) to "encode" the context surrounding each word used in a given text into a feature vector. The BERT encoder is a deep-learning-based Large Language Model (LLM) that was trained, in part, by masking a random selection of 15% of the words in a large corpus of text and predicting each masked word using its adjacent words (see Web Appendix A for graph). The BERT encoder generates a 768-dimensional feature vector for each word in a text. This feature vector captures contextual information around the focal word by summarizing the surrounding words-the same information the model would rely on to predict the focal word if it were masked. Notably, BERT produces different feature vectors for identical words appearing in different linguistic contexts because it encodes how a word is used in the text (the word context) rather than the word itself. 2 (See Table 1 for an illustration of how our method captures differentiation based on the context in which an emotion label is used, rather than solely relying on the specific emotion label itself.). 3

Computing Differentiation between Feature Vectors. Once the feature vectors for each emotion label in a given piece of text are calculated, we use the Cronbach's alpha statistic to capture the degree of differentiation between the contexts in which these words are used. The Cronbach's alpha statistic is traditionally used to measure the internal consistency of a set of items (e.g., survey questions) that are intended to assess the same underlying construct. 2 BERT encodings are structurally different from word embeddings produced by other models such as Word2Vec (Mikolov et al. 2013) and GloVe (Pennington, Socher, and Manning 2014), which have been used in earlier consumer behavior research (Berger et al. 2019). In Word2Vec and GloVe, a word's embedding is the global representation of that word across the entire training corpus. Thus, these models produce the same embedding for identical words regardless of the context in which the word is used. However, BERT produces the feature vector representing a word's context, which is needed to predict the target word. This is why for two identical words that are used in different contexts, BERT produces different feature vectors. 3 We have included the vanilla Python code for measuring emotional granularity using our approach in Web Appendix A. Our implementation customizes this vanilla code by incorporating optimizations such as vectorization, memory management, and multi-core/parallel processing to enhance processing speed. Both versions produce identical results. On the same machine (using a GPU), the vanilla code would take approximately 75 days to process all the field data in our paper, whereas our optimized implementation reduces this time to about 7 days. each word's vector representation as an item and considering the set of emotion labels as the "construct" (the "construct" in our application could be viewed as the contextual meaning represented by these "items"). A high Cronbach's alpha (closer to 1) would indicate that the feature vectors (i.e., the "items") represent highly overlapping contextual meanings. Conversely, a low Cronbach's alpha (closer to 0) would suggest greater differentiation, implying that the words are used in distinct contextual meaning spaces. For ease of interpretation, we subtract this statistic from 1 so that a higher score indicates higher differentiation and granularity. 4 Note. An illustration of how our measurement approach captures the context in which emotion labels are used, rather than focusing solely on the labels themselves. In each example, differentiation scores are calculated by computing the 768-dimensional BERT feature vector of the words uncomfortable (from Sentence 1) and irritated (from Sentence 2), calculating the Cronbach's alpha statistic of these two vectors, and subtracting the result from 1. Despite the focal words being identical across all examples, the differentiation scores vary. In Example 1, the words are used with slightly different contextual information (mention of sick child in Sentence 2 but not in Sentence 1), thus the differentiation score is higher compared to scores in Examples 2 or 3, where the words are used with identical contextual information. It is important to note that while this illustration computes differentiation scores across separate sentences for clarity and control, our actual method does not require breaking the text into sentences. Instead, we compute the feature vectors of different words within the full text, allowing us to assess differentiation based on the broader context in which the words are used.

div.head: STUDY 1: ASSESSING OUR MEASUREMENT APPROACH
div.p: The main purpose of study 1 was to evaluate our proposed method for calculating the emotional granularity in language by comparing it with the commonly used experiencesampling-based measurement of emotional granularity, which is currently the predominant method being used to measure emotional granularity in psychological research. Experience sampling studies often involve measuring participants' emotions several times a day through the course of several weeks. However, Cameron and colleagues (2013) have successfully adapted the method for a single experimental session. Specifically, to measure participants' granularity in negative emotions, these authors presented their participants with a set of 10 images and measured the extent to which participants felt anger, guilt, sadness, and shame in response to each image. They then computed participants' trait-level granularity in negative emotions by computing the intra-class correlation coefficients (ICCs) of these ratings. In study 1, we adapted these authors' method to the consumer behavior context to measure participants' experiencesampling-based granularity in negative emotions. More Specifically, we recruited 605 participants (MAge = 42.8, SD = 13.1, 53.5% females) from CloudResearch and presented them with 10 short consumption scenarios (e.g., "You've been a loyal customer to a brand for years, but you notice they send personalized discounts to new customers and not to you."; see Web

Appendix B for stimuli). For each scenario, we asked participants to rate how much it would make them feel anger, guilt, sadness, and shame on scales ranging from 1 = not at all to 5 = extremely. Following Cameron et al. (2013) we computed the z-score normalized ICCs of these ratings for each participant and multiplied this number by -1 to compute the degree of trait-level negative emotional granularity of each participant. stimuli) and asked participants to imagine themselves going through this experience. Next, we asked participants to indicate how many stars (out of five) would they give to this restaurant if they were to rate it on a website like Yelp. Finally, we asked participants to write a review of this restaurant in about 50 words as if they were reviewing it on Yelp. We computed the granularity of negative emotions expressed in this review using the deep-learning-based method described earlier (a total of 211 reviews did not receive granularity scores because they did not include 2 or more negative emotion labels).

We reasoned that if our measure indeed captures participants' situation-level emotional granularity in expressing their negative emotions in text, as a conservative test, the negative emotional granularity score computed through our method should correlate with the trait-level scores produced using the experience sampling method. Results support the validity of our proposed method by confirming a correlation between the two negative emotional granularity scores (r = .104, p = .040).

Furthermore, if emotional granularity in negative emotions is associated with emotional self-regulation 5 and more positive rating of unpleasant service experiences, both the experiencesampling-based negative granularity measure (trait-level) and our deep-learning-based negative granularity scores (situation-level) should correlate with more positive ratings of the restaurant.

Supporting our theoretical predictions, both the experience-sampling-based (r = .086, p = .031) and the deep-learning-based (r = .118, p = .019) negative emotional granularity scores were correlated with higher ratings of the restaurant.

Another goal of study 1 was to explore whether granularity in negative emotions can be distinguished from other emotion-related constructs. To assess the distinctiveness of the negative emotional granularity from complexity of negative emotions, we computed the number of unique negative emotion labels used in the review text, because using more negative emotion labels may indicate higher complexity. The number of unique negative emotion labels in the review text was not associated with emotional granularity scores derived from experience sampling (p = 0.833).

This result supports the distinction between emotional granularity, as a trait-level skill, and emotional complexity. The number of unique negative emotion labels in the review text was negatively correlated with granularity in expressing negative emotions within the review (r = -0.575, p < 0.001). This latter result does align with our conceptualization of emotional granularity: A single context can evoke only a limited range of emotions. Because more granular individuals have a more precise cognitive structure for different emotions, they choose emotion labels more selectively, and only if the labels apply to the specific context, which causes a negative correlation when descriptions of a single context (i.e., the restaurant experience) are considered.

Furthermore, to assess the distinctiveness of granularity in negative emotions from extremity of negative emotions, emotional certainty (Rocklage et al. 2023), and participants' degree of focus on negative emotions (i.e., negative "emotionality"; Rocklage et al. 2015), we used The Lexical Suite (see Rocklage and Fazio 2015 for operationalization of variables in The Lexical Suite), to compute the review text's score on each of these constructs. (Since our granularity measure focuses on negative labels, we focused on the emotionality and extremity scores that the Lexical Suite produces for negative emotions). None of these variables predicted the experience-sampling-based negative granularity scores (p-values > .196) or the deeplearning-based negative granularity scores (p-values > .335). 6 These results suggest differentiation between emotional granularity and these other constructs.

The results of study 1 provide preliminary validation of our method to measure emotional granularity in text, while disentangling the construct from other emotion-related constructs. The correlation table of all measured variables are presented in Web Appendix E.

div.head: STUDY 2: MANIPULATING THE CONTEXTUALIZATION OF EMOTIONS
div.p: The aim of study 2 was to validate our assumption that our deep learning-based method for measuring emotional granularity in language effectively captures individuals' likelihood of contextualizing their emotions. A total of 393 students (MAge = 20.1, SD = 1.5, 47.1 females) from a large public university in the US participated in the study for course credit. All participants watched a short news clip about Delta Airlines removing a family with an infant from an overbooked flight. Importantly, we manipulated participants' likelihood of contextualizing their emotions by instructing them to either focus solely on the emotions they might have experienced during the incident or to consider the contextual factors that led to the incident. More specifically, participants in the control condition were asked to "put yourself in the mistreated customers' shoes. Focus on the emotions they might have experienced during the incident. Make an effort to imagine what it would feel like to be in their situation and to experience those emotions." Those in the contextualization condition were instead asked to "imagine yourself in the airline's position. Consider the possible reasons behind the airline's decision, such as policies or procedures they may have been required to follow that didn't account for an unexpected situation like this. Focus on understanding the context that could explain why the airline acted as it did, even if the outcome was unfortunate." Thus, the manipulation influenced participants' likelihood of contextualizing their emotions by either directing them to focus solely on the raw emotional responses caused by the event or prompting them to incorporate nuanced contextual factors into their emotional appraisals (Lazarus 1991).

After watching the video all participants were asked to take a few minutes "to describe in detail the negative emotions that you experienced from watching the video." We calculated the negative granularity scores of these descriptions to investigate whether participants who were instructed to consider contextual information would describe their negative emotions more granularly than participants in the control condition. We were able to calculate the negative granularity scores for 170 participants in the contextualization condition and 190 participants in the control condition. As expected, an ANOVA showed that participants' expressions of their negative emotions were more granular if they were instructed to contextualize their emotions (M = .25, SD = .11) than not (M = .20, SD = .09; F(1, 358) = 16.79, p < .001, h 2 p = .045).

Furthermore, to dissociate our construct from other emotion-related constructs, we calculated all the variables that were calculated from the review text in the previous study to explore the effect of our manipulation on them. Participants who were instructed to consider the context, used fewer unique negative emotion labels (M = 3.10, SD = 1.49) than those who were not (M = 3.91, SD = 1.60; F(1, 391) = 26.68, p < .001, h 2 p = .064), which is again consistent with the idea that emotional granularity is correlated with being selective in using emotion labels. However, the effect of the manipulation on the granularity expressed in the reviews persisted if controlling for the number of unique negative emotion labels (F(1, 357) = 4.33, p = .038, h 2 p = .012), demonstrating that our measure of emotional granularity captures more nuanced information within the text beyond this correlated measure. The manipulation did not influence the extremity of negative emotions (F(1, 360) < 1; p = .627), the negative emotional focus ("emotionality") (F(1, 360) < 1; p = .731), or the certainty (F(1, 368) < 1; p = .499) expressed in the essays. 7

These findings further validate our measure by demonstrating that it captures individuals' tendency to contextualize their emotions, while other emotion-related constructs do not show the same sensitivity to this distinction.

div.head: STUDY 3: EMOTIONAL GRANULARITY AND REVIEW RATINGS
div.p: The purpose of study 3 was to test our propositions regarding the relationship between granularity in describing negative emotions in the review text and review ratings using a large dataset of online consumer reviews. We collected over 11 million reviews from over 52,000 Yelp reviewers, ensuring that the dataset includes all reviews from each reviewer in the sample.

We have predicted that higher granularity in describing negative emotions in the review text is associated with a more positive rating of the business, but especially in the case of negative service experiences. We used the LIWC software to measure the overall positivity of the text of the review as a proxy for the quality (positivity) of the service experience. We investigated how the granularity with which negative emotions are described in the review text,
interacts with the quality of the service experience to predict the 5-star rating given in the review.

In addition, we explored the potential applicability of granularity in describing negative emotions as a psychological targeting and profiling tool. We thus computed a historical granularity index for each reviewer at the time of writing each review by averaging all the negative granularity scores of the reviewer across all their reviews written prior to the focal review. We investigated how this historical granularity index interacts with the quality of the service experience to predict the review rating.

div.head: Data and Measures
div.p: Review data. The data for this study was gathered from Yelp. Yelp reviews include qualitative textual comments and a star rating on a 5-point scale. The platform also allows users to create a profile and to follow other users and be followed by them. We adopted a snowball sampling approach (Zhang et al. 2020) to create our dataset. As the first step, we began with one prolific reviewer on Yelp and collected all reviews written by this individual. In the second step, from this reviewer's profile, we extracted the list of their friends and collected all reviews written by a random sample of 20% of them. Finally, from the reviewers in our second step sample, we identified a random sample of 20% of their friends and collected all their reviews. This sampling approach ensured that our data includes all the reviews of each reviewer in our dataset. Given that our text analysis approach was limited to English, we removed all non-English reviews from our dataset. Through this process, we obtained 11,272,283 reviews, written by 52,804 reviewers, in a period between July 2000 and September 2021.

Perceived Experience Quality (Review Valence). As a measure of the overall positivity of the service experience, we computed a perceived experience quality index for each review using the LIWC software (Pennebaker et al. 2001) by subtracting the percentage of negative words from the percentage of positive words in each review.

Granularity in Negative Emotions. For each review, we computed the granularity with which the reviewer has described their negative emotions in that review using our method explained earlier. Since some reviews contained less than two negative emotion labels, a total of 3,343,739 reviews did not receive a negative granularity score.

Granularity in Positive Emotions. We used the same method to also compute granularity in positive emotions (but this time by considering positive emotion labels) to be used as a control variable and to explore the effects of granularity in positive emotions. Again, because some reviews contained less than two positive emotion labels, 398,244 reviews did not receive a positive granularity score.

Linguistic Precision. One may wonder if the effects observed in our results are because reviewers specifically use negative emotion labels with precision or because they simply use all words in the vocabulary with precision, perhaps because of higher language sophistication. To remedy this concern, as a control variable, we calculated a linguistic precision index for each review by applying our method to all non-emotional words in the review, excluding stop words (e.g., "this", "and", etc.). A total of 811 (very short) reviews did not receive a score.

Historical Granularity and Linguistic Precision Indexes. We computed a historical negative granularity index for each reviewer at the time of writing each review by averaging all negative granularity scores of the reviewer for their reviews that were written prior to the focal review. We also computed similar historical indices for positive granularity and linguistic precision.

Other Control Variables. As other control variables we computed the number of unique positive and unique negative emotion labels used in the review to control for possible effects of emotional complexity and ambivalence. We also included the word count of each review as a control variable.

div.head: Analyses and Results
div.p: Granularity in Review Text and Review Ratings. We conducted a multi-level regression (Model 1.1 in Table 2), predicting review rating with the fixed effects of negative granularity, perceived experience quality, and their interaction, while controlling for the fixed effects of positive granularity, positive granularity × perceived-experience-quality interaction, linguistic precision, number of unique negative emotion labels, number of unique positive emotion labels, and the word count of the review. We also included the reviewer random intercept in the model.
For the ease of interpretation of the results, we Z-score normalized all independent variables in this model and all subsequent models. The full results of this regression are presented in Table 2.

For brevity, we discuss only the results that are central to testing our predictions. The more granularly the reviewer described their negative emotions in the review text, the more positively they rated the business (b = .07, S.E. = .0005, t = 142.72, p = .000, 95% CI = [0.069, 0.071]). We had predicted that the effect of negative emotional granularity on rating would be stronger when perceived experience quality is negative because self-regulation of negative emotions is most relevant to experiences that are negative overall. In support of this prediction, we observed a significant negative granularity × perceived-experience-quality interaction effect (b = -.14, S.E. = .0005, t = -272.40, p = .000, 95% CI = [-0.141, -0.139]). As shown in Figure 1, simple slope analysis revealed that, in reviews that described a more negative overall experience (M-SD), the more granularly the reviewer described their negative emotions within the review text, the more positively they rated the business (b = .19, S.E. = .00, t = 286.73, p = .00). However, the effect of emotional granularity on rating was attenuated for reviews that described an overall positive experience (M+SD; b = .00, S.E. = .00, t = 3.19, p = .00).

Interestingly, granularity in positive emotions was associated with more negative ratings (b = -.16, S.E. = .0006, t = -251.56, p = .000, 95% CI = [-.161, -.158]). We had not made a priori predictions regarding the effects of positive granularity. However, a post-hoc interpretation of this effect may be that describing one's positive emotions more granularly is associated with a higher likelihood of considering the representativeness and relevance of one's feelings for the rating judgement (i.e., "I enjoyed my coffee at this café, but the weather-though unrelated to the café-contributed to this feeling"; Pham 1998), which may reduce the total sum of the impact of positive feelings on ratings. Furthermore, we also observed a significant positive granularity × perceived-experience-quality interaction effect (b = .03, S.E. = .0005, t = 57.62, p = .000, 95% CI = [.029, .031]). Simple slope analysis suggests that the association between positive granularity and negative ratings was stronger in reviews that described a more negative experience quality (M-SD; b = -.19, S.E. = .00, t = -309.46, p = .00) than a more positive service quality (M+SD; b = -.15, S.E. = .00, t = -190.10, p =.00). This interaction effect, which was much smaller than the one with negative granularity, is not parallel to what was observed with negative granularity: a parallel result would be to observe a stronger association in reviews that describe a more positive experience. A post-hoc interpretation of this interaction may be that when the experience-quality is negative, contextualizing positive emotions leads to an even lower attribution of the positive emotions to the business ("The only thing good about this hotel was its beach but that's because all beaches on this Island are nice").

div.head: FIGURE 1
div.p: THE EFFECT OF NEGATIVE GRANULARITY AND PERCEIVED SERVICE QUALITY Historical Emotional Granularity and Review Ratings. To investigate whether the effects found in Model 1.1 with situation-level negative granularity hold by considering historical negative granularity scores, we conducted another multi-level regression (Model 1.2 in Table 2) that predicts the rating of each review with the fixed effects of that experience quality, the historical negative emotional granularity index of the reviewer of that review, and the interaction of these two factors. In this model, we also controlled for the fixed effects of the reviewer's historical positive emotional granularity index, the historical positive granularity × experience quality interaction, the reviewer's historical linguistic precision scores, the number of unique negative and positive emotion labels in the review, and the word count of the review. We also included the reviewer random intercept in the model. The full results of this regression are also presented in Table 2. Consistent with our situation-level analysis from Model 1.1, we observed that reviewers' greater propensity for describing negative emotions in their prior reviews was = 0.00, t = 78.49, p = .00). However, we observed a negative association between the historical negative granularity and ratings if the focal review described a positive experience (b = -.02, S.E. = 0.00, t = -34.13, p = .00).

Exploring the effects of positive granularity, as with the situation-level analysis, we observed a significant negative association between historical granularity in positive emotions and ratings (b = -.04, S.E. = 0.001, t = -41.52, p = .00, 95% CI = [ -.042, -.038]). We also observed a significant historical positive granularity × experience quality fixed interaction effect (b = -.01, S.E. = .0003, t = -29.39, p = .000, 95% CI = [-0.011, -0.009]). However, as opposed to the situation-level analysis before, the association between positive granularity and negative ratings was stronger in reviews that described a more positive experience quality (M+SD; b = -.04, S.E. = .00, t = -49.30, p = .00) than a more negative experience quality (M-SD; b = -0.03, S.E. = 0.00, t = -29.45, p = 0.00). A possible interpretation is that individuals' historical positive granularity may also capture some of the variance in individuals' trait-level self-regulation abilities in managing negative emotions, as one expects those with higher granularity in negative emotions to also have higher granularity in positive emotions.

Robustness Checks. To check the robustness of our results if controlling for extremity of negative emotions, emotional certainty and the negative "emotionality" expressed in the reviews, we conducted the two regressions above while controlling for these variables as calculated by the Evaluative Lexicon. The conclusions from our results remain unchanged (see Web Appendix F for robustness check results, and Web Appendix E for correlation tables of all measured variables). Note. All p-values are significant below the .0001 level.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In study 3, we used a large sample of reviews from reviewers on Yelp to conduct an analysis of the relationship between granularity in describing negative emotions in the review text and reviewer ratings. First, we found evidence consistent with the notion that the granularity in describing negative emotions is associated with better self-regulation of negative emotions.

Self-regulation of negative emotions is most relevant in situations where the overall service experience has been of low quality. We measured the overall negativity of the review text as a proxy for the perceived quality of the service experience. Accordingly, we observed that especially when perceived experience quality was low, granularity in describing negative emotions was associated with more positive ratings of the business. We observed this effect at two levels. First, at the situation level, we observed that granularity in negative emotions in a specific review resulted in the above effect. Second, we observed that a reviewer's historical granularity in describing their negative emotions in their prior reviews is associated with more positive ratings, particularly for low quality service experiences. This latter result is important because of its implications for consumer targeting and profiling, as the analysis uses traits inferred from reviewers' earlier reviews to predict their future ratings.

div.head: STUDY 4: MANIPULATION OF THE LIKELIHOOD OF EMOTION REGULATION
div.p: The purpose of study 4 was to provide process evidence that the observed effect of granularity in negative emotions on ratings is because granularity facilitates the self-regulation of the unwanted impact of negative emotions on rating decisions. If the effect is driven by emotional self-regulation, then instructing participants to avoid regulating their negative emotions should weaken the correlation between granularity in describing negative emotions and ratings. To test this, we recruited 404 participants (MAge = 41.15, SD = 13.6, 49.5% females)
from Prolific and randomly assigned them to either a control or an avoid-regulation condition.

We first asked all participants to recall a recent unpleasant service experience and to describe the negative emotions from it in about 50 words. Afterward, participants in the control condition were asked to provide a star rating for the business (1 = 1 Star, 5 = 5 Stars), as if reviewing it on a platform like Yelp. Those in the avoid-regulation condition were also instructed to rate the business at this stage, but with the additional instruction to focus solely on how bad they personally felt due to the experience and to rate the business based only on this feeling. Thus, compared to the control group, participants in the avoid-regulation condition were explicitly discouraged from regulating their negative emotions when forming their rating-i.e., regardless of whether the emotions were attributable to the business or not.

We were able to compute negative granularity scores for 359 participants. We conducted a linear regression to predict ratings with condition (0 = control, 1 = avoid-regulation), negative granularity scores (centered), and their interaction. As expected, instructions to avoid self- These results support the idea that granularity in negative emotions is associated with more positive ratings of the business because contextualizing emotions helps individuals selfregulate the impact of their negative emotions on their rating decisions. Notably, additional

regression analyses we have conducted shows that the effect of extremity in negative emotions, the focus on negative emotions (negative "emotionality"), and emotional certainty-calculated using The Lexical Suite from participants' essays-on ratings, is not moderated by our manipulation (all interaction p-values > .479), further dissociating our construct from these other constructs.

div.head: STUDIES 5A AND 5B: TEMPORAL DISTANCE AND EMOTIONAL GRANULARITY
div.p: We argue that the lower viscerality of negative emotions resulting from temporal distance enables individuals to consider the context in which they experienced those emotions and to express them more granularly. In studies 5A and 5B we investigated the causal effect of temporal distance on the granularity with which individuals express their negative emotions.
In study 5A, we leveraged the presidential debate between Kamala Harris and Donald

Trump on September 10, 2024, which was widely perceived as a victory for Kamala Harris, and thus an unpleasant experience for Trump supporters. We recruited a total of 574 (MAge = 43.2, SD = 13.7; 52.4% females) Trump supporters through CloudResearch. We utilized the platform's prescreening surveys to target US participants who had indicated "very" or "somewhat" favorable attitude towards Donald Trump, were planning to vote for Donald Trump, and were planning to watch the presidential debates. Participants were simply asked to spend a few minutes describing, in about 50 words, the emotions that they experienced from watching the debate. Importantly, a total of 301 participants completed the survey 2 days after the debate whereas 273 participants completed it 10 days after (we intended to recruit 300 participants for the second group. However, there were not enough participants on CloudResearch with the prescreened characteristics and we stopped the survey after two days of inactivity). We were able to compute negative granularity scores for 242 participants in the first group and 229 participants in the second group. As expected, participants who wrote their essay 10 days after the debate (M = .34, SD = .13) expressed their negative emotions more granularly than those who wrote it 2 days after (M = .31, SD = .12; F(1, 469) = 4.29, p = .039, h 2 p = .009).

To dissociate emotional granularity from the other emotion-related constructs, we also computed the additional set of variables that were calculated in the previous studies. The manipulation did not influence the number of unique negative emotions labels used in the essays (F(1, 572) < 1; p = .383), the extremity of the negative emotions (F(1, 438) = 1.71; p = .192), the degree of emotionality of the negative emotions (F(1, 438) = 2.03; p = .155), or the certainty (F(1, 528) = 2.03; p = .544) expressed in the essays.

In study 5B, we adopted a more controlled approach. We recruited a total of 505 participants (MAge = 37.6, SD = 12.5; 59.8% females) from CloudResearch and asked them to first watch a short clip of the movie "The Champ", which depicts a young actor grieving their deceased father, and has been used in previous research as a sad stimulus (e.g., Faraji-Rad and Lee 2022). Participants were then asked to describe in detail the emotions that they experienced from watching the clip. Importantly, one randomly assigned group of participants (no-time-gap condition) described their emotions immediately after watching the video; whereas the other group (time-gap condition) were first asked to write about a typical day in their life and then write about their emotions.

We were able to compute negative granularity scores for 211 participants in the time-gap condition and 224 participants in the no-time-gap condition. As expected, participants who wrote their essay with a time gap after watching the clip (M = .26, SD = .11) expressed their negative emotions more granularly than those who wrote it immediately after (M = .23, SD = .09; F(1, 433) = 9.28, p = .002, h 2 p = .021).

In contrast to the previous study, in this study, participants in the time-gap condition (M = 3.09, SD = 1.85) used fewer unique negative emotion labels than those in the no-time-gap condition (M = 3.66, SD = 1.77; F(1, 503) = 12.59, p < .001, h 2 p = .024). However, the effect of the manipulation on emotional granularity remained marginally significant when controlling for the number of unique negative labels (F(1, 432) = 3.48, p = .063, h 2 p = .008). The extremity of the negative emotions (F(1, 425) = 1.23; p = .268), the "emotionality" of negative emotions F(1, 425) < 1; p = .331), or certainty (F(1, 452) < 1; p = .543) expressed in the essays were not affected by the manipulation.

The results of these two studies provide causal evidence that individuals describe their negative emotions from an experience more granularly if there is a greater temporal distance between the experience time and the description time. Furthermore, the observation that the temporal distance manipulations in these studies do not consistently influence the other emotionrelated constructs helps further differentiate the emotional granularity construct from the other emotion-related constructs: if the different measures were measuring the same construct, we would expect them to behave similarly in response to the manipulation.

div.head: STUDY 6: TEMPORAL DISTANCE, GRANULARITY, AND REVIEW RATINGS
div.p: In study 6, we used a sample of reviews from TripAdvisor.com that included all reviews of all hotels in New York and Las Vegas listed on TripAdvisor. The study's first objective was to replicate the interactive effect of experience quality and granularity in describing negative emotions on review ratings. To ensure the robustness of our findings, we used two proxies for experience quality. As the first proxy, consistent with study 3, we used the valence of the focal review's text, which captures the reviewer's own description and perceptions of the service experience. The second proxy was the normative average of the experience qualities described across all other reviews for the business, excluding the focal review. This measure provides a more objective-and more conservative-assessment of service quality beyond the perspective of the focal reviewer.

The second purpose of the study was to test our propositions regarding the effects of temporal distance between a service experience and the writing of the review using information extracted from TripAdvisor.com. In studies 5A and 5B we observed that the temporal distance between an experience and describing one's emotions from it increases the granularity with which negative emotions are described. In study 6, we tested whether a greater temporal distance is associated with greater granularity in describing negative emotions in the review text.

Furthermore, we investigated whether the increased negative granularity resulting from the greater temporal distance predicts a more positive rating of the business, especially when overall experience quality is negative.

div.head: Data and Measures
div.p: Review data. We collected the entire set of reviews for all hotels in New York and Las Vegas on TripAdvisor.com that were available up to the time of data collection. This resulted in a total of 1,343,518 reviews spanning 18 years (2003-2020) from 591 hotels. Similar to Yelp,

TripAdvisor enables users to share and evaluate their experience with service providers in the form of qualitative textual comments and a star rating on a 5-point scale. We collected review texts, review ratings, when each review was posted, and when the service was provided.

Temporal Distance. TripAdvisor provides the month when the visit to the hotel took place (e.g., Dec 2023). Thus, to measure temporal distance, we counted the number of months between the time of the visit and the date when the review was posted. This number was then log transformed for incorporation into the model. We excluded a total of 1,278 reviews that produced a negative temporal distance, which suggested that either the reviewer reviewed the service before visiting it, or that the time of the visit was incorrect.

Perceived and Normative Experience Quality. We computed a perceived experience quality index for each review following the approach used in study 3. Additionally, the structure of our dataset, which includes all reviews for each hotel, allowed us to derive a second measure of experience quality: the normative average of the experience qualities from all other reviews of the focal business, excluding the focal review itself. This measure provides a more objective assessment of experience quality, as it reflects the collective experiences of other reviewers and is less likely to be confounded with variables specific to the focal review. However, it serves as a conservative estimate, as a hotel's service quality can vary over time and across customers.
Therefore, we use it to test the robustness of our results based on the first measure.

Granularity in Negative Emotions. Using the proposed method explained earlier, for each review, we computed the granularity with which the reviewer has described their negative emotions in that review. Since some reviews contained less than two negative emotion labels, a total of 573,752 reviews did not receive a negative granularity score.

Granularity in Positive Emotions. For use as a control variable and also to explore the effects of granularity in positive emotions, as in study 3, we computed a positive granularity score for each review. Again, some reviews contained less than two positive emotion labels.
Therefore, a total of 42,646 reviews did not receive a positive granularity score.

precision index for each review. Six very short reviews did not receive a score. As other control variables we computed the number of unique positive and unique negative emotion labels used in the review, as well as the word count of each review.

div.head: Analysis and Results
div.p: Granularity in Review Text and Review Ratings. We first tested whether the results of study 3 on the relationship between negative granularity and review rating would be replicated with the current dataset. We conducted a multi-level regression (Model 2.1 in Table 3), predicting review rating with the fixed effects of negative granularity, perceived experience quality, and their interaction, while controlling for the fixed effects of positive granularity, positive granularity × perceived-experience-quality interaction, linguistic precision, number of unique negative emotion labels, number of unique positive emotion labels, and the word count of the review. We also included the hotel random intercept in the model. The full results of this regression are presented in Table 3. We focus on the results that are pertinent to testing our predictions. Replicating the results of the previous study, negative emotional granularity was associated with higher ratings (b = .12, S.E. = .001, t = 76.94, p = .000, 95% CI = [.118, .122]).

We again observed the predicted negative granularity × perceived-experience-quality interaction effect (b = -.15, S.E. = .002 t = -93.19, p = .000, 95% CI = [-.154, -.146]). As in study 3, simple slope analyses revealed that in reviews describing an overall negative service experience (M-SD), the more granularly the reviewers described their negative emotions, the more positively they rated the business (b = .27, S.E. = .00, t = 129.50, p = .00). However, the effect of emotional granularity on rating was attenuated for reviews describing an overall positive experience (M+SD) (b = 0.06, S.E. = .00, t = 31.88, p = .00).
Exploring the effects of positive granularity, we observed effects that were consistent with model 1.1 in study 3. We will thus not discuss them further here.

The Effect of Temporal Distance on Negative Granularity. We predicted that a greater temporal distance increases reviewers' likelihood of describing their negative emotions granularly. To provide support for this prediction, we conducted another multi-level regression (Model 2.2 in Table 3), in which we predicted negative granularity of the reviews with the fixed effects of temporal distance, perceived experience quality, and their interaction, while controlling for the same control variables that were included in Model 2.1. The full results of this regression are presented in Table 3. As expected, we observed that greater temporal distance is associated with a higher level of granularity in describing negative emotions in the review (b = .01, S.E. =.001, t = 12.26, p = .000, 95% CI = [0.008, 0.012]).

The Effect of Temporal Distance on Review Rating. We have predicted greater temporal distance to be associated with higher review ratings, especially when the overall service quality is low. To test this, we estimated another multi-level regression (Model 2.3 in Table 3) to predict review rating with temporal distance, perceived experience quality, and their interaction, while also including the same control variables that were included in Models 2.1 and 2.2.

The full results of this regression are also presented in Table 3. A greater temporal distance (b = .03, S.E. = 0.001, t = 40.43, p = .000, 95% CI = [0.028, 0.032]) was associated with more positive ratings. However, importantly, we also observed a temporal distance × perceivedexperience-quality interaction (b = -.03, S.E. = .001, t = -42.05, p = .000, 95% CI = [-0.032, -0.028]. When perceived experience quality was low, greater temporal distance was associated with a more positive rating of the business (b = .06, S.E. = .00, t = 57.18, p = .00). Interestingly, however, when perceived service quality was positive, a greater temporal distance was only minimally associated with the review rating (b = -.00, S.E. = .00, t = -2.06, p = .04), which is consistent with our self-regulation/coping-based argument of the effect of temporal distance:

when the overall experience is positive and thus, emotional self-regulation does not apply, reviewers' improvement in negative granularity caused by temporal distance does not contribute to more positive ratings. Table 4, were consistent with what was observed with the reviewer-level service quality scores (Table 3), demonstrating the robustness of our findings across both quality scores.

Furthermore, similar to study 3, we tested whether the conclusion from results would substantively change if we controlled for extremity of negative emotions, emotional certainty, and degree of focus on negative emotions. They do not (see Web Appendix G for these robustness check results, and Web Appendix E for correlation tables of all measured variables).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Study 6 replicated the result of study 3 by showing that particularly when the overall experience is negative, higher granularity in describing negative emotions in the review text is associated with a more positive rating of the business. We observed this effect both when considering the reviewers' own perceived experience quality expressed in the review, and when considering the normative experience quality of the hotel as described by other reviewers. Consistent with the causal evidence of the effect of temporal distance on negative emotional granularity in studies 5A and 5B, we also observed that temporal distance is associated with higher granularity in describing negative emotions. Importantly, we also observed the consequences of this increased granularity on the rating assigned to the business through a moderated mediation analysis. We observed that when the overall experience is negative, greater temporal distance is associated with more positive ratings, and this effect is mediated by granularity in describing negative emotions. On the other hand, when the experience is positive, and coping is not relevant, temporal distance does not improve ratings. These results are important as they demonstrate that individuals' granularity in describing their negative emotions may be impacted by situational factors, with implications for coping with negative experiences and review ratings.

div.head: GENERAL DISCUSSION
div.p: Studies show that over 90% of consumers use online reviews as a source of information to guide their purchases (Forbes 2022), and even a single review rating has a strong effect on consumers' purchase likelihood (Vana and Lambrecht 2021). These facts make consumers' decisions on how to rate a business, following negative service experiences (e.g., service

failures) an important one to study. We studied consumer's online review rating decisions from the perspective of consumer coping, and by considering the degree of granularity with which reviewers describe their negative emotions in their reviews. Although the notion of emotional granularity has received considerable attention in the psychology domain over the past three decades (e.g., Barrett and Gross 2001;, to date, research in marketing and consumer behavior has not investigated its implications for consumer decision making.

Our research contributes to the online review literature by providing evidence of the impact of granularity in negative emotions on review ratings, following service failures.
